I purchased this game for my blind daughter to try. I loaded up the game for her, and let her play.  It is 100% accessible from the first menu through the end of the game.  She was completely engaged in both the story and gameplay, and didn't want to stop playing.  Between play sessions, she told us about the characters and what was going on, and she was excited about it.  It took her 8 hours of game time to complete the game, and I'm sure she will go through it again, as she didn't want it to end.  Thanks to the developers for the quality experience, and I hope you think about a sequel or more games like this one!

[b]First: [/b]
Play with a good headset and close your eyes. The immersion and game experience will be far better than with open eyes and normal loudspeakers.

[b]Now to the game itself:[/b]
This is a very unique game, since you experience the whole game from the eyes of a blind woman, meaning you won't see anything. So you will rely on your hearing and orientate and fight through audio cues. The cast delivers an awesome job in bringing the characters to life and I always wanted to know how the story continues. While this game won't be for everyone, I had 6 hours of fun (time didnt count in steam somehow) and can attest, that not only blind gamers will like this one.

For the negative points: I played the game in 30 minutes bursts, because after that time I had to pause. This is one of the best video games I've ever played, and I finished it with my eyes closed. The Vale is an audio-based game that is best played with headphones. The only graphics are floating colored spheres that don't help you so you might as well just close your eyes. But this is not just a glorified audio book. It's an actual game. 

The game uses audio cues and directional sound to direct you to attack and block in one of three directions. It sounds simple but the combat actually gets more complex as it unfolds with hunting with bows and arrow, a little magic, parrying, heavy attacks, interrupting attacks, etc. It was just so cool to close your eyes and listen to the direction of the enemies and block and attack. It was so incredibly unique. The audio aspect gave me some Hellblade vibes.  I chose to play on the hardest difficulty. It was challenging at times but totally fair and it made the combat and the game even more immersive.

You play as a blind female protagonist who is led by a guide in a fantasy realm where enemies are after her. The devs created an incredible female protagonist and it was really cool to have no video as it put you in the shoes of the protagonist as she is blind and can only respond to the sounds of her environment as well. It was a massive step up in terms of immersion. 

The main story and voice acting were really high quality and I really enjoyed how it all unfolded at the end. The entirely verbal story felt surprisingly intimate. It was an all-around beautiful experience. There are even side quests in the game that had a unique way of being unlocked and played. You follow sounds in a town square, are prompted later to press a button to start the quest, and then you travel to a self contained area to complete the quest. 

You might be traveling and come across an inn with shops nearby. You’ll hear the sound of sword smiths working on swords, the banging of steel. Walk towards that if you wanna buy and sell gear there. You might hear chickens in the distance which will tell you it’s a spot you can buy food and stuff. You can go inside inns and take on side quests. I had one quest where you had to find treasure behind a waterfall. Well you and your companion search for said waterfall and you’ll hear it in the distance. 

The game is also fully accessible to visually impaired as all the menus are voiced like the inventory menu. It's a pretty great thing that someone who is visually impaired cannot only relate to the protagonist but can also fully play a video game.

I feel like a lot of people write it off pretty quick because you’re blind in game and see nothing, but it’s so much more than that. The story is good. It’s an RPG at heart. The combat is actually engaging and makes you focus and listen carefully. I never had a game tell you and show you so much without having anything on screen. 

It was such a unique experience to, well, experience something simply by only sounds. I had to pay attention to the things I would normally not even notice consciously.  It was definitely weird at first, I was totally looking for visualy but got used to it after a bit. I loved the ending too, I somehow did not expect that. 

I have to say, that even despite the negatives and the drawbacks outlined by some, I think this game deserves a standing ovation for really trying something new and being very innovative, and I sincerely hope more of this type of thing becomes a thing. While I'm not blind, nor do I know anyone who is (that would be likely to play video games), I just love that this was made.

I use corrective lenses, contacts and glasses.  When I take them off, I cannot see any words on my computer screen, have limited depth perception, and cannot tell objects apart unless their colours are dynamically distinct from their surroundings, I played and streamed a bit of this without any corrective lenses and it felt absolutely wonderful.  Worn glasses since 8 years old with gradually deteriorating eyesight ever since.  So corrective lenses have always been my normal, but when I played this game, even streamed it, I was comfortable and entirely engaged.  Even the little "stars" (just dots but to me they looked like stars) of colours that I could see without my lenses were a pleasant touch because they gave me to option to see something if I wanted to.  To rely on hearing more was so satisfying for the combat and is an aspect that is easy to take for granted in just about every other game.  I remember telling my friend when he was playing a jump rope challenge FFIX to closes his eyes and listen for the sound cue because that would be more accurate than his vision.  We enjoy sound in stereo for movies and audio books and tv shows, why not for games too?  

The story is very engaging and the voice actors they found for it we very well done.  I forgot I was streaming while I played this game. Even the voice for the menu screens was pleasant and didn't sound out of place with the dynamic of the story so I could remain in the story world even when I had to bring up stats menu or main menu screens.

I was not expecting the quests I got.  It made the world in which the story takes place come alive as not all of them are part of the main story.  It would have been just fine if the developers just made a story and had you just play that as a nice adventure tale.  But they took time to make a world with people who have wants, needs, greed, desires, all walks of life and the actors add many details that helped all of that build and come together in my mind's eye.

What's the most satisfying feeling for me, though? I get sick usually playing first person games.  The camera motions make me queasy.  This is the first game I have been able to say I can play first person. And honestly, that's enough to make me cry for joy.

So, yes, get this game, Try this game...but most of all, tell people that this game and this developer exists.

This graphics-less “audio game” works pretty intuitively, and it's deeper than I initially expected. It plays like Punch-Out with stealth and RPG elements. But blind combat is otherwise a satisfying (and steep) challenge.

The real star of the show is the dialogue, which feels surprisingly organic and intimate. Tightly written, beautifully voice acted, and weaved into the mechanics, it fits the game like a glove. I don't want to spoil anything other than the fact that the dialogue caught me off-guard.

After finishing this game I felt compelled to write a review.

Have you ever wondered what it would be like being blind? What it truly entails? This game gives you a glimpse in what life would be like being blind. The concept is unique; You play as a blind woman traversing a medieval world. As you are playing a blind woman, you literally stare at a black screen (with coloured lights to reflect the type of environment that you are in) for a few hours.

The feat accomplished here is not small; the players engagement entirely depends on the voice acting, and the story being told. The vale does this masterfully. 

The vale has an incredible sound design, which makes you feel immersed in the world that it is presenting itself to you. The game made it a point to make sure the player understands that while being blind is limiting, you are in no way helpless. Everyone relies on somebody, and this is no different in the game.

Movement relies on the sound stage (hence the recommendation of headphones). You navigate the world purely based on sound. This can be a fun, but also perhaps a terrifying experience. Since you have no visual on anything, you literally only have sound to go by. This is also reflected by the main characters state when things unbeknownst to her are happening; she can only infer based on sound. This also applies to the combat in the game. Based on directional sound, the player needs to either block or attack at the right time based on sound cues. This makes for a very fun (albeit sometimes hard) experience to survive combat encounters (based on the difficulty setting).

I really recommend you try out this game, its an experiance in and of itself.

The Vale caught my interest as it is a completely audio-based game, something I have never encountered thus far.

It's comparable to an audio drama, expect for the added agency you have via the gameplay, which is surprisingly fun with various elements that switch it up every now and then. It, together with the excellent sound design and voice acting, made for an immersive, unique experience I would very much like to see more developers test around with. The in-game menus can be navigated by audio only, but are of course also visible. Headphones are a must as you need to differentiate between the directions sounds are coming from in combat.

The only thing I would have liked is just... more. I loved Alex's story, the people she met along the way, as well as the RPG mechanics. But it really is quite short, so be aware of that. 

To conclude, I'm glad I stumbled upon this game and I hope other developers pick up on its ideas and the potential it has, for accessibility's sake and for pushing the medium itself.

It's difficult to explain in words just how special this game is, but I can try.

The Vale is, quite simply, marvelous. In this game, you play as a blind princess in a medieval fantasy world filled with monsters, bandits, and soldiers trying to kill you. Yes, this game is designed to be played without vision, but make no mistake, that's not a gimmick here. This is a full, complete game, with a rich world, RPG elements, side quests, branching paths, moral choices, the works. If anything, removing the visuals opens up an entirely new style of play that I've never had the chance to experience before. You are listening for every footstep and sword swing, using your ears to guide you through the experience. It's intensely gratifying and rewarding, and it's backed up by the best sound design in the business. The Vale places you into a vivid and lush world, and because you need to really focus on hearing everything around you, it feels like you're really there. It says something that the most immersive game I've played in years has no visuals.

The Vale includes a surprisingly complex combat system, with enough depth and choice to satisfy a wide variety of playstyles. Stealth and ranged combat are both options, as well as magic, and different methods of hand-to-hand combat. Throw in a few incredible boss fights and a bunch of different enemy types, each with their own attack pattern, and you got a recipe that will please any fan of action.

Of course, the real highlight in my mind is the story. All the characters here are wonderfully fleshed out, carried by some spectacular voice acting and great chemistry. The plot is filled with enough intrigue and twists to keep me not only interested but invested. I admit, there were a handful of moments where I did tear up a bit. And, not to get into spoilers, but The Vale sticks the landing with a satisfying ending.

If you're put off by the concept of playing an action RPG with no visuals, trust me, you do not want to miss this. Rather than detracting, it adds an entirely new dimension to a formula that had been getting stale for some time. The Vale is the kind of game that sticks with you long after you're done with it. If anything, it's worth it just to support a developer doing great work on making games accessible. Go on this journey. You won't come out the same way.

Oh, and it should go without saying, but you're gonna want a good pair of headphones for this one.

A classic well-written story about a blind princess' journey through a country under invasion.

This is a game that is played by following the sound queues, it is fully sound-based and everything is voiced, all the menus and options included. Fully accessible for people with visual impairments and is a worthy experience for anybody else.

The sound engine is quite simplistic, especially compared to other games with strong superiour sound work (example - Hunt: Showdown), but it is serviceable.

So is combat - serviceable. Enemies attack from three sides with audio cues (some of them are harder to decode than others), each enemy type has different patterns of attacks (there are 5 types of enemies, some vary their patterns, some have a gimmick). You have 2 types of attacks, directional block, stamina management (no stam bar) and a couple of extra abilities. 

The voice work is well-produced and well-written, despite the fantasy tropes, The music is ok, so are the visuals - you get some if you wanna look at your screen.

The whole game can be completed in about 5 hours.

While being nothing special as a fighting marvel, it is a game that tries and, in my opinion, prevails at a goal of making a uniquely accessible game. Considering it's made by a small team, The Vale is a gem of a journey.

Worth buying, playing and supporting.

If the idea of a game that you can play with your eyes closed interests you, then you should definitely play The Vale. It features a touching and gripping story with great characters, and it explores its audio-led gameplay in many interesting and creative ways.

I highly recommend checking out The Vale.

I hate to leave a negative review here, because this game is a very cool attempt at something both artistically new and morally correct. I mean, hey, removing the video part from video games? Making a game completely without a visual aspect, which also doubles as making it accessible to blind people? What's not to be intrigued by in this proposition?

The problem with The Vale is simple. It's just not very good of a game. It's ingenuity ends at the concept. To back this opinion let me bring up some statistics: ~80% of people have killed the first enemy, ~50% have completed the first side quest, ~25% have completely finished the tutorial, and only ~15% have beaten the game. Considering the game's rather short - 6-10 hours - that's a pretty rapid dropoff rate, don't you think? 

Oh, but you could say that this is because playing as a blind person is probably not very fun for most people. That might be true, and indeed, it could be the reason for those low stats. To me, however, playing while blind was actually by far the best part of the game. I even played blindfolded, so that my brain would completely shut off the "seeing" functionality. Having my mind construct the world purely on the soundscape and how it changes was [strike]eye opening[/strike] quite something.

[h1]The Gameplay: Combat[/h1]
So how does it play? During fighting, you press arrow keys to attack an enemy that is standing in a given direction. Which direction? Use your ears. The enemy might block, so it's possible you'll have to attack when they're getting ready to strike themselves. Or block and counter. Sometimes you'll even have to face multiple enemies at once; headphones absolutely necessary.

Now that sounds pretty sweet, doesn't it? That's the thing. It gets boring pretty fast.

And this is arguably the biggest issue with the game. You fight quite a bit, and yet fighting simply doesn't feel good. I mean; I can confidently say the devs juiced it up as much as possible. The slash sounds, the footsteps, the grunts and screams, all top notch. But I feel like the format itself is just... not that fun. 

[h1]The Gameplay: Other[/h1]
You also get to walk around a bit. That's much more interesting, having to navigate purely based on sound. It's a lot more fun than it sounds, and noticing the sounds spicing up your idea of the world is also quite amazing. Sadly, again: once the novelty runs out it just becomes... flat.

There's also some system of managing weapons and inventory. Navigating the menus is not fun as well, probably because you have to hear the explanation of what options are there and how to choose between them. I feel like this part could've been done better, but how? Using shortcuts maybe? 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
I'm not going to lie, I wouldn't know how to make a good game in which you can't see a thing. This is definitely a noble attempt, and we need more of those - if nothing else, so that one eventually gets it right and creates a completely new way to include lots of previously excluded people in the world of video games.

All my complaints... for blind people this is probably normal, in which case I'm really sorry. I'll never take my sight for granted, and I hope that one day technology allows you to perceive the world the way we, seeing folk, do. Or at least to give us a game that both groups of people can enjoy just the same. This one is probably not it, even if it's arguably worth playing just to understand how the world looks like to those who can't see.

When I got The Vale I thought it would be just a novelty accessibility game for the blind. It certainly fits that category, but I got a little more than that. I am sighted, so I used a blindfold/darkness and played with a keyboard and mouse. Surround sound headphones are pretty much obligatory, since essentially every gimmick relies on your ability to detect the directions of sounds in the environment and combat.

You play a blind princess in a medieval setting. Most of this is pretty cliche, but some characters add some personality to pull you along the narrative enough to stay interested. Being purely audio, the voice acting and music is pretty good, as you could expect. I also felt like the directional aspects of the surround sound were very accurate and played well to the main designs around this concept.

I do think that the plot thickens and twists near its abrupt end, which is a shame. It took me around 10 hours to complete, but it felt like it could have been summed up better in another hour or two of more deliberately unraveling some of the story's complexities instead of oversimplifying its resolution.  

The game follows a pattern where you go from destination to destination as a "base" in which you find a few quests/town interactions where you must rely on sound to avoid hazards and attack/defend in combat. You get a bow, heavy or light weapon, armor, and shield to upgrade over time in a linear fashion. I don't see why someone would play and not do all of the few quests in each town, so you're never out of money and there is not much choice there. This system could have been expanded slightly, I think. You also gain an ability later on that can affect different aspects of combat that has different ways of being upgraded, as well as forks in the story that you do choose to change, albeit with the same ultimate destination.

The uniqueness of gameplay of The Vale is enough to try, and its quality for being developed by such a small group is admirable and impressive. I definitely recommend it for any PC gamer who wants something different, and, of course, for those without sight, I cannot speak to how this experience would be for them, but I think it would still be fun and challenging.

The Vale could quite conceivably be played with your monitor turned off as every element of the menus and interface is spoken along with clear instructions of what buttons you should be pressing.  But an accessible UI is just the beginning.  How do you make a 5+ hour adventure/RPG engaging and entertaining with absolutely no conventional graphics?  It’s well known that when one of your senses stops functioning the others will compensate, and in this case it’s all about the audio.

So the game starts off with you, a young girl, traveling by wagon to your new castle on the outskirts of a kingdom now under rule by your brother, the new king.  Blinded at birth, you can only hear the creaking of the wagon and the plodding of hooves until your wagon is stopped by a guard who says they are under attack from an invading army and you should flee at once.  Again, everything is voice and sound effects only with nothing more than dust motes swirling around the screen; purely artistic with no relevance to the actual game, nothing to give sighted gamers an unfair advantage.

From this moment you are on your own as you must complete the long and perilous journey home through the winding valley known as The Vale.  In true RPG fashion you’ll need to equip yourself with a weapon; a variety of weapons in fact along with magical abilities and the occasional companion to aid you on several quests while always relying on your most powerful ability…your hearing.  Your ability to identify and locate danger through audio alone is something quite unique.  Hearing a growling wolf is one thing but listening to the subtle changes in that growl to nail the perfect timing of your attack is another.  At first you’ll likely being swinging your stick around wildly, much like any newly blind person would, but once you settle down and learn to listen you can actually start to enjoy the engaging combat system that will slowly rise in difficulty as you learn to mix light and heavy attacks with perfectly timed counters and even learn to fire a bow.  You’ll eventually face off against multiple enemies at once, learn to listen for archery fire, and even traverse some surprisingly terrifying stealth sections.  The sinister audio in these moments really sparks the darkest parts of your imagination.

Introduction
The Vale is not long and some may find the gameplay simple, but it’s enjoyable with fantastic sound and a solid story. 
Story
You are a blind princess. At the game’s start, you’re on your way to take residence in a frontier castle. And then the Vale’s Golden Horde equivalent arrive and ruin your day. Now you’re retracing your journey to bring word to your brother. 
It’s a pretty straightforward start, but there are some twists later. Hopefully at least one of them will come as a surprise.
Gameplay
The Vale is an audio game, so there are no visuals. You alternate between free-roam and combat mode.
Free-roam is much like any first person game. Moving around, interacting with things, and talking with people. You’ll need to use audio to guide yourself though. 
In combat, you’re locked in place. Attacks come from left, right, or ahead. You’re basically engaged in a series of quick time events, listening for attacks to know when and in what direction to raise your shield and then strike back. 
As with other action RPG games, you’ll be able to acquire new equipment as the game progresses. These items are armour (take less damage when you do get hit), shields (block stronger blows), bows (used in certain sequences), and weapons (you can use swords, hammers, or axes). 
You’ll also pick up some magical abilities later, which are used in combat.
I found the gameplay satisfying. The gear upgrades felt like I was improving. Each weapon type also felt slightly different. There’s also bonus points for everyone’s favourite early quest: killing rats in the cellar.
Audio
The game’s big draw. All the audio is fantastic. The voice acting is great, combat sounds satisfying, and environment noises solid. 
Particular highlights are the alehouse scene with all the patrons singing together and the battle scene later in the game. In fact, that battle scene is the most immersed I’ve ever felt in a video-game combat experience. It’s all thanks to the audio.
Conclusion
The Vale isn’t long, perhaps 5-6 hours for a single playthrough. I enjoyed every minute of it though. It’s a great little game and I hope the developers go on to build on it in the future. Perhaps next time we can even get that other most coveted RPG trope: the sewer level.

The Vale is a bit of a rough gem, but fortunately it's worth is greater than the sum of its parts.

First off, this game is a pretty novel experience, relying entirely on the soundscape to drive its narrative, game play and action elements. For me, it's like playing a good "Choice of... " game (a series of choose your own adventure e-gamebooks) in that the minimalist graphics allow the player to invest in their imagination, which can bring the world more to life than some other standard games do. It also reminds me a bit of "Unheard", in that the player needs to focus intently on the soundscape for clues, again drawing the player further into the experience. For that alone, it's worth experiencing at least once.

The game isn't perfect, of course. The combat, while polished and enjoyable, can start to feel a bit repetitive towards the end of the game. Combat does have it's fun points, especially where you are presented new types of foes, having to listen to totally new audio cues, as well as adapt to new behaviour patterns. It's a pity that these weren't done more in the game. The bulk of combat eventually simplifies into a pattern of waiting to block, strike back, abandon combo strikes if needed to block multiple opponents, repeat. Despite the juicy options of throwing heavy strikes and casting magic, ultimately this is the dull but most effective way to proceed. There were also missed opportunities for the combat system to shine. For example, if the player could execute timed rhythm combo attacks, or precisely timed perfect blocks at the moment of an opponent's strike (in the style of Death's Gambit), that would entice and challenge players to play more skillfully and take more risks. 

Magic is, likewise, a bit lackluster. Despite how much the game emphasizes your character's skill in magic, magic basically boils down to one AoE and one critical chance modifier, both of which end up not changing the routine combat pattern at all. Again there is a missed opportunity here to do creative stuff like raise a rock wall to protect one side (a character was shown to be able to bring down a mountain avalanche), cast darkness or blinding light (so that, as a seasoned blind fighter, you gain a huge upper hand as your opponents flail blindly), an adrenaline rush type skill to remove endurance drain, or some kind of super sensory focus to filter out distracting background noises (the chaos of the soundscape in a full on melee fight between armies at the end part of the game was terrifying and exhilarating at the same time). These are merely ideas that feed directly into the game's combat system, and already they are much more varied than what the game has.

Story-wise, the game is ok. This is more of an audio book and less of an RPG, in that there are very few times you get to make a decision in the game, and these decisions basically boil down to taking path A over B, with the only consequence being fighting different groups of enemies. The story doesn't change. There's also no time limit or consequences to side quests, so the logical thing to do is to take on all side quests. It would have been nice to have certain side quests conflict with each other, or have lasting tangible consequences. Over time you stop paying attention to your companion's pleas to think about your own safety too, which doesn't help with story immersion.

Despite these imperfections, the game is great to experience at least once, and still highly recommended!

I play Sniper Elite 5 on authentic[/i]") after losing the multi-enemy fights about twenty times each on [b]normal[/b] difficulty. This game is an excellently rendered audiogame. It has a diverse cast of characters and a fairly diverse cast of actors. Other than some simple "where should we go" style choices, you are also in charge of what weapon, shield, and armor you wear. There are honest tradeoffs here: will you be a slow, heavily armored fighter who bashes through everything? Will you be a lightly armed flash who sneaks about and attacks with speed? The story won't change very much from playthrough to playthrough, but your choices do effect the style of combat you take, the risks you take, and some of the interactions you have. Overall, it's a well done game that, while a little shorter than I'd like, offers hours of entertainment.

The game is entirely in first person, and works by sections: you travel to a village and have stealth/combat/story moments during this travel.
Then you arrive to a village, and have a number of sidequests to do and equipment to buy.

There are two different gameplay sequences:
- The ones where you are moving your character while locating yourself with sound cues, these can be stealth sections, more action oriented, or when you are moving around in a village
- The ones where you are fighting, you will have to fight using your ears in front/on the left/on the right. Your character doesn't move during these sections and everything is done with the two sticks (on xbox controller).

A few critics:
- It didn't happen often, but there was two times where the auto-save system made me miss side-quests because I didn't understand it would make the game go to the next "chapter". Most of the time you can cancel a side-quest and go back to it later.
- Some game mechanics where not very clear even after the tutorial, and it took me some time to understand them.

Superbly unique in concept, [i]The Vale: Shadow of the Crown[/i] stood out to me as a very interesting title. I was so intrigued and curious, in fact, that I ended up buying the game, installing it, and started playing it all in the very same evening. As someone who's normally got an exceedingly long process from discovery of a title to sitting down and playing it, this is unheard of. 

Happily, I was not let down. It was interesting to explore how this type of game differs from more typical games, as well as how playing video games might be experienced by sight-impaired individuals. I almost exclusively played through the game wearing a blindfold, although that is not necessary.

Gameplay-wise, the controls can take some time to get used to, but feel satisfying once one pulls them off. The difficulty is too uneven, especially comparing early and late game (I played on normal), spiking somewhere along the way. The different types of weapons seem at first to suggest that experimenting with different combat strategies is encouraged, but the actual fights one ends up in often require one strategy over any other, and so there is little room for experimentation in practice. In several towns the smith has also only got one weapon for sale, further locking one out from experimentation. The magic mechanic seems largely pointless: you unlock the ability not long before the end, and so there are few opportunities to use it, explore it, and level it up. (I don't know the extent to which any of these things apply to any of the other difficulties than normal.)

At times it was difficult to keep up with what was going on, making me confused as to what was happening, or had just happened. For example, at one point I had to infer after the fact that someone had probably succumbed in the confrontation I had just lived through. It could very well be argued that this is just how it is for people who rely in most part on their hearing for outside information, however.

The story seems simple at first, but is nevertheless enjoyable. However, it abruptly gets rather involving towards the end, and I couldn't help but feel more invested. It would've been nice to have that happen earlier, and not shortly before it is all over.

The sound design is magnificent, though it needs to be for this kind of game to work well. Paired with the nice voice work and 3D audio, it certainly makes for an immersive world, which has a massive impact on the enjoyment of a game like this.

What I enjoyed perhaps most of all was learning to take in information to make my decisions based on sound, instead of sight, by relying on audio cues to determine where the enemy is, and how they will attack. That certainly makes for a positively unique experience, and I am sure to come back for more.

[b]Verdict:[/b] 7-/10

The Vale was one of the best RPGs I have played in recent memory. Its unique style of replacing visuals with a purely sound-based experience is extremely refreshing in an ocean of other titles which follow the same formula time and again. 

In terms of mechanics, the use of directional sound has you sneaking past enemies, aiming a bow towards the source of a noise, and blocking and trading blows with enemies from different directions. You learn to listen out for the creak of armour as an enemy changes position, the rush of footsteps as they charge towards you, arrows whistling through the air towards you. It truly is an experience like no other. For these systems to work the best it is highly recommended to use a quality pair of headphones so you can get a full sense of the directional sound, and a controller makes combat thoroughly enjoyable and gripping.

These systems are carried through by a strong narrative and decent world building, with characters showing satisfying depth and quality through stellar voice acting. In short, just get the dang game :P

This game is actually quite incredible. The story and voice acting is amazing, and I found myself drawn in from the very beginning. The biggest surprise came from the fact that the gameplay was actually very fun! I enjoyed myself from start to finish. There's a very reasonable learning curve, and it was never too difficult (or too easy) thanks to just the right amount of tutorial sprinkled throughout what was going on.

The plot was intriguing, and it kept developing the further I went along. The characters are all unique and grow on you over time and make you care. Even the side quests never feel dull or like a waste of time.

I used a sleep mask over my eyes and played with headphones and a controller, and the immersion was completely worth it. This was a truly unique experience, and I would absolutely purchase a sequel if one ever came out. Don't even wait for a sale -- this game is worth full price.

This was a really unique experience and thoughtfully designed around its concept. The voice acting and sound design are top notch as you might hope for in an audio-centered game. The script is very well written and, as someone not super into the fantasy genre, engaging and memorable without becoming overwhelmingly trope-y and the length feels just right. 

The quests, tutorials, and dialogue scenes are thoughtfully cut into short segments and the gameplay is kept simple in all regards, almost too simple at times although it would likely become confusing with much more going on (and in a few scenes it can overload you a bit with audio information). Combat is basically a slightly more complex whack-a-mole but it is quite impressive that it works as well as it does.

I find this to be a nice compliment to a game like Return of the Obra Dinn that is also about listening carefully but in a more puzzle focused way, in contrast to the action adventure focus in this, and while Obra Dinn has a distinct visual style as well, this offers a complete immersive audio experience that by the end had really engaged my imagination in a way I've not experienced in a game before (but have in narrative podcasts).
Overall I must say great game! I loved the story line and most of all how it allows the player to make important choices. Must have for any true gamer rather your blind or not!
the voice acting, music, and sound design is spot on. its easy to get immersed into the game.
A nice game that was unfortunately short, hope for a sequel. It was well tuned, and funny. Nice story.

Pros: A wholly unique video game experience that is playable entirely without the need of vision. Great voice acting and sound effects all around. I am very interested in Radio Theater and this game is fascinating as a concept.
The Vale is also surprisingly strong narratively, and the choice to make the main character blind makes perfect sense. A lot of the audio devices/narrative tricks used to describe flashbacks, and death/respawns are really smart. Example: If she dies in battle, it sounds like she passes out, only to wake up suddenly, saying she had a premonition of the threat ahead (it was only a dream when she died), and the game then offers you a choice to try that again or go a different way, because of your foreknowledge.

Cons: The gameplay is fairly limited, due to the constraints of the medium. At its best, it feels like a proof of concept of what could be an entire genre of games. 
If something like Oculus Rift were leveraged, it would greatly improve the game by allowing you to turn your head towards sounds and swing your arms. The greatest weakness of The Vale is that stereo sound can only offer so much, and the developers chose to only present sounds in front of and to either side of the player, never behind (because behind sound exactly like in front). Even so, what the game manages to offer is surprisingly engaging considering it is entirely audio based. This is an rpg complete with movement, combat, and equipment management all done without any visuals at all. All menus can also be navigated without sight.

If you want a very unique and interesting concept for a video game, and especially if you have any interest in games accessible for vision impaired people, definitely check this game out.

I'm really glad I'm not blind though, when purchasing items in this game! Going through the stats on gear, with my eyes closed, is a merciless process at first, trying to remember all the details..
I also find it tedious to listen to the narrator's help comments every time I need to choose quests or being told how to accept whatever, using my spacebar - being blind is not equal to being imbecile, I CAN remember simple functions. I mean, when speech and sound are the only things the player relies on, maybe avoid wearing me down with them..
On the other hand, if I zoned out during a side-quest briefing, I'm screwed, since there's no way to have them repeat the issue at hand..

The baker fight was super difficult, mainly because the kid does this fireball combo from each side in very quick succession (how that works, I've no clue! I can clearly hear him growl to my far right, how does he hit my left side, without moving??), which, in order to block, you have to know that the shield actually lingers in a position even though you've started blocking the other direction. Some narrative stuff; Shepherd being pessimistic about every side-quest I wanna do, felt kinda bad. I think it's awkward if games like this can only be about the player character being blind. It's an obvious story, and they handled it well, but I'm sure this doesn't have to be the case in a game like this. - just a thought..

Last little thing; I didn't care for the pop-piano filler in the beginning - it felt really out of place compared to the rest of the soundtrack.

The Vale: Shadow of the Crown is a groundbreaking audio game that sets a new standard for interactive storytelling, especially for the blind community. As a visually impaired gamer, I was immediately drawn into the immersive world of The Vale, where the story of Alexandra Denholm unfolds with a richness and depth that is rarely seen, or rather, heard in gaming.

The game's narrative is compelling and deeply personal, resonating with me on many levels. Alexandra Denholm's journey is one of courage, resilience, and discovery, and it was a joy to experience her story. The interaction feels so natural and intuitive that I was completely engrossed, making choices and navigating through the game world with ease.

One of the standout aspects of The Vale is the character of Abdul Rashid, also known as Shepherd. Shepherd is not just a guide; he is a mentor, a protector, and a friend to Alexandra. His wisdom and experience provide Alexandra with the strength and knowledge she needs to navigate her perilous journey. Shepherd’s calm and reassuring presence is a constant source of support, and his deep, resonant voice adds a layer of authenticity to his character. Through his eyes, Alexandra—and by extension, the player—learns to "see" the world in a new way, relying on sounds, smells, and tactile sensations.

Shepherd's backstory and his own journey parallel Alexandra's in many ways. He, too, has faced loss and adversity, and his journey of redemption and service adds depth to his character. The dynamic between Shepherd and Alexandra is beautifully crafted, with moments of tension, humor, and heartfelt connection. Their relationship evolves naturally over the course of the game, from one of necessity to genuine friendship and mutual respect.

Alexandra Denholm, the game's protagonist, is a character of remarkable depth and complexity. Despite her noble birth, she is thrust into a world that requires her to rely on her wits and inner strength. Alexandra's determination and bravery are inspiring, and her development throughout the game is both believable and compelling. She is not a passive character; her choices and actions drive the story forward, making her an active participant in her own fate.

The developers deserve high praise for their innovative approach and dedication to accessibility. The voice acting in The Vale is exceptional, bringing each character to life with authenticity and emotion. Every voice actor delivered a stellar performance, enhancing the overall immersion and making the story even more engaging.

In conclusion, The Vale: Shadow of the Crown is a must-play for anyone who appreciates a well-crafted story and values accessibility in gaming. It is a remarkable achievement that showcases the power of audio storytelling, and I cannot wait to see what future chapters hold for Alexandra Denholm and Shepherd. Great work to the entire development team and voice actors for creating such an unforgettable experience.

The Vale: Shadow of the Crown, or The Vale, is an action adventure game from Falling Squirrel and Creative Bytes studios.

You play as Alex, a blind princess sent to a distant castle in her brother’s kingdom. After surviving an invading army’s surprise attack, you need to find your way back to safety while learning about the world, the war and your place in both.

The Vale is uniquely experienced only via audio. Its only visuals are particle effects indicating motion, weather, and time of day. The game even reads the menus aloud, presumably allowing people with visual disabilities to enjoy the game without aid.

Much of The Vale relies on the player deducing directions and distances using only sound. For example, enemy combatants telegraph upcoming attacks with yells, allowing you to raise a shield or time counterattacks in that direction. Evading enemy camps may require listening for their crackling fires or banter. Good headphones help, as does enabling any 3D or directional audio enhancement. 

The Vale executes well. Most challenges are intuitive or quickly learned. You return to the challenge’s start if you fail, sometimes with a short hint. However, discerning multiple incoming attacks while using your abilities can be tricky in the more complex fights. 

Communicating setting and dialog solely via voice can be slow. However, The Vale‘s script is tight. Descriptions are vivid and concise, and I never got bored or frustrated waiting for dialog. The choices of accents and voice acting are brilliant, immediately identifying the speaker. 

The story is similarly tight and has many twists and reveals. Flashbacks teach skills and build relationships. “Flash forwards” unexpectedly show incorrect paths.

Removing visuals also awakens the player’s imagination. Like reading a novel, you wonder what characters and scenes look like based on accents and the occasional brief but lucid description.

The Vale makes you realize how visuals dominate games. Even for games that use stylized or simplified graphics, simple things like art and animation dominate the language used to describe them.

The Vale also reinforces that game accessibility is not about reducing the difficulty. Accessibility is about reimagining and redesigning game interaction and content. 

That said, The Vale is still niche. Visuals are more effective at quickly communicating information and adding emotional context than sound. Using sound for feedback means the game cannot have a soundtrack. The Vale will not dethrone any AAA games from the top sellers’ charts.

The Vale is also short, requiring about eight hours to complete, including all side quests. The game introduces ideas, uses them a few times then moves on to the next ones.

The Vale succeeds as a game, experiment and tech demo, and it will appeal to those looking for something unusual, those with visual impairments or students of game design.

Hopefully, these ideas spread and are enhanced or included in other games. Imagine the same techniques applied to imaginative, story-rich, graphics-lite games like Disco Elysium or Planescape: Torment.

I played the demo of The Vale and knew immediately that I wanted to play the full game, but I still had no idea just how good it would be.  A great story and excellent gameplay, all wrapped in really thoughtful presentation and execution!

The story, optional quests and combat system are interesting enough to keep you engaged during the more or less 6 hours of gameplay.

In the walking part of he gameplay you orientate yourself by listening to sounds in the surrounding like merchants, water, fire or enemies talking, which in some cases you can avoid with stealth. But those parts are quite short and you will not get lost at all.

Combat consists of blocking, light/heavy attacks and counters. When fighting multiple enemies it requires some concentration and timing but it is not too hard and you can adjust the difficulty. With bow and arrow you always have enough time to aim carefully, especially in the optional hunting quests.

The equipment upgrades are quite basic but at least allow you to choose between a slow/heavy or fast/light fighting style, but don’t expect anything RPG-like here.

Overall it was quite relaxing to enjoy the story and combat with closed eyes

Por temas laborales no pude seguir jugando pero realmente es uno de los pocos juegos (que jugué) que está bien diseñado y tiene una buena historia. El hecho de jugar con una persona no vidente y sentir como sería una gran aventura es algo muy bien logrado.

Hablar de The Vale implica abordar un juego bastante único en su género. ¿A qué género pertenece? Es difícil decirlo. A nivel jugable, podría tratarse de una aventura gráfica o de una novela narrativa, o quizá de ambos. A nivel temático, estamos ante un juego de rol, pero también de acción y aventura. ¿Y cuál es nuestro rol en todo este entramado de acciones? Lamentablemente, es una pregunta que la aventura no responde del todo por sí misma. Se trata de un vistazo, del comienzo de una aventura más grande, en cuyo centro operan fuerzas poco claras que en esta ¿primera parte? apenas conocemos.

Pero lo cierto es que, a pesar de ello, se trata de un juego formidable donde solo usaremos nuestra audición para orientarnos en un mundo a oscuras, ya que estaremos en la piel de una princesa guerrera que es, a su vez, una persona ciega. Y dicha ceguera, por supuesto, no solo no será un impedimento para el combate, sino la llave para la elaboración de un sistema de combate en el que nos guiaremos por el sonido para saber de dónde vienen nuestros atacantes, así como qué tipos de ataque van a realizar. En cada uno de esos casos, tendremos distintas acciones, como contraatacar, bloquear, anticiparnos con un ataque y hasta... mejor lo dejo para que lo descubran ustedes. De todas maneras, hay que hacer una pequeña salvedad: aunque la pantalla esté prácticamente en negro, habrá pequeñas motas de luz que se irán moviendo a medida que transcurra la aventura, las cuales nos indicarán si estamos caminando o si estamos quietos, si es de noche (motas azules) o de día (motas amarillas), etcétera. Si llueve, serán azules y caerán como cualquier lluvia de toda la vida, así que a nivel visual también tiene su encanto.

La trama, por otra parte, podría resumirse en un viaje de regreso, atravesando The Vale o El Valle, un espacio comprendido entre el punto en el que empezamos y el punto al que debemos volver (Glades, a quinientas millas de distancia), que a su vez da título al juego. En dicho viaje nos acompañará Shepperd ('pastor'), que nos llamará Sheep ('oveja') en ciertas ocasiones. Así, con la fiel compañía de este personaje y otros que nos iremos encontrando a lo largo del camino, pasaremos por pueblos llenos de vida y otros desolados en los que nos esperará una aventura a la vuelta de cada sonido.

Todo en este juego es hermoso. Pero siempre podemos encontrar algunas cositas que podrían haber estado mejor. Lo primero que lamento es que el misterio detrás de ciertos eventos importantes para la trama no se termine develando, aunque imagino que es porque habrá pensada una secuela. Lo segundo: está inglés y, debido al público al que va dirigido principalmente (personas ciegas), no tiene subtítulos. Esto hará que solo quienes entiendan inglés esuchándolo puedan comprender la trama y disfrutarla verdaderamente.

Solo queda esperar una secuela que termine de explicar por qué esas fuerzas misteriosas actúan del modo en que lo hacen. y, sobre todo, cuál va a ser nuestro verdadero rol en todo eso.
